neighbors.name: Penn Comm Of Game Commission
neighbors.claims: The Pennsylvania Game Commission manages over 1.5 million acres of state game lands across the Commonwealth [PA Game Commission](https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/pgc/huntingandtrapping/where-to-hunt/state-game-lands.html). This includes several State Game Lands located in Schuylkill County, indicating the agency is a major landholder in the area [PA Game Commission](https://www.pa.gov/en/agencies/pgc/huntingandtrapping/where-to-hunt/state-game-lands.html).

approach_recommendations.engage: Coordinate with the Game Commission’s regional office and emphasize wildlife habitat protections to address any concerns.

neighbors.name: Fanelli Limited Partnership I
neighbors.claims: Fanelli Limited Partnership I is a private Pennsylvania partnership identified in county records as a landowner in Schuylkill County [Schuylkill County Assessment](https://gis.vgsi.com/SchuylkillCountyPA/). The partnership’s principals maintain a low public profile, with no mention found in local news or civic records, suggesting it functions mainly as a passive property holding entity.

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out discreetly via the partnership’s registered agent or mailing address to understand their interests, as direct community channels are absent.

neighbors.name: Thomas Milowicki
neighbors.claims: Thomas Milowicki is listed as an owner of property in the area but appears to reside outside Schuylkill County. He was noted in federal court filings as the owner of a firearms range business in southeastern Pennsylvania [Justia](https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/pennsylvania/paedce/5:2015cv02485/504276/14/), indicating his primary business and likely residence are not local.

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage via direct contact (e.g., phone or mail) focusing on factual project information, as he is an absentee owner with no known local involvement.

overview_summary: All three profiled neighbors are landowners with no clearly documented stance on development or energy projects. One is a state agency holding extensive game lands (high influence due to its institutional authority), while the other two are private owners with limited or no visible community involvement (low overall influence).
